clues.text: A competition for the top prize in a sports league
The status of belonging to an organization, or the number of people who belong to one
A joint business, like Scrooge & Marley's
An authorized trading establishment, perhaps for cars
Absolute rule by an individual, like Hitler
On April 19, 1775 8 Minutemen lost their lives in Lexington; 2 more were lost at North Bridge near this town to the west
On Dec. 7, 1787 in a 30-0 vote, this state ratified the Constitution, the first state to do so
This Quaker leader spent only 4 years in the colony & future state with his name on it, leaving for good in 1701
In the 1750s & 1760s the colonies were torn by this war known in Europe as the Seven Years' War
In print for about 25 years, this annual publication by Benjamin Franklin sold about 10,000 copies a year
You're too old for the single-piece type of underwear that Gerber trademarked under this name
"Loony" game similar to Uno in which you try to get rid of all your cards on the discard pile
Hyphenated word that describes the 2-level buses of London
In the Old West, a gun that held half a dozen bullets went by this alliterative term
Ancient Rome was once led by one of these trios whose name comes from the Latin for "three"
Kipling said the camel's this "is an ugly lump"
Elizabeth Anna Hart wrote about "Mother Tabbyskins", this type of animal
Ted Walker cleverly likened this colorful pet fish to the "spillings of rich coins on a miser's table"
Emily Dickinson's poem about this kind of animal begins , "A narrow fellow in the grass" & ends, "zero at the bone"
Coleridge, not Poe, wrote a poem with the question "Where then did" this bird "go?"
Though now flourishing, this church didn't officially exist in England from the 1500s to 1850
In 1913, E. Davison, to publicize cause of women's suffrage, threw herself under this king's horse
He became prime minister in 1964, the youngest in the 20th century
This racy monthly which promoted 1892 Corbett-Sullivan fight was a barbershop favorite
"Newsweek" spoke of "the power of the press" when B. Bain's dog was killed by copy of this heavy paper
Time, Inc. spent $85 million in a futile attempt to save this D.C. paper
He was a successful playwright as well as author of "War & Peace"
"Drama" comes from the word meaning "to do" in this ancient language
Ionesco's "The Bald Soprano" is an example of this style of theater
His symbolism in "the Great God Brown" involved the use of masks by actors
Grieg wrote music for the 1st production of this Ibsen classic
Middle East Airlines
Varig
The opposing coaches at this Feb. 3, 2013 event were brothers Jim & John Harbaugh
Zero players were elected into this sport's Cooperstown Hall of Fame in 2013
The 2012 U.S. women's gymnastics team had this numeric nickname
In an interview with Oprah, he finally admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs to win the Tour de France
An iPhone commercial featured these 2 sisters playing ping pong instead of tennis
This Philistine said, "Give me a man, that we may fight together"; only David answered the call
This disciple "went unto the chief priests, to betray" Jesus
This king's "wisdom excelled the wisdom of all the children of the east country, and all the wisdom of Egypt"
Before this strong guy's birth, an angel came to his mother saying, "No razor shall come on his head"
Once a persecutor of Christians, Saul changed his name to this after his conversion

rounds.text: A 1954 act amended a 1938 one by striking out this word & replacing it with "Veterans"
